utterance: Cathy Murphy: We've got all kinds of people joining us here plus a bot. Okay, groovy. Okay, so we have an hour and 15 minutes to get ourselves organized, so to speak, in this session on phase separation. Okay, so welcome everybody. I'm Cathy Murphy. I know some of you already, but maybe we'll and I guess I'm the only facilitator here. So maybe we can go around real quick. I'll call on people as I see you on my screen and what I'd like us to say is like your name, where you, you know, what department and university you're from, what your general thing is in terms of your science, and then in terms of phase separation, what your interests are in terms of this session. Okay, so I'll make myself a template here. So I'm Cathy Murphy. I'm in chemistry at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. I'm a nanoparticle person, and so we normally do a lot of synthesis and surface chemistry and some biological applications and some environmental implications. We are interested in some proteins that don't have a structure and like can they form a structure on a nanoparticle surface. So my interests in phase separation in a cell would kind of be along those lines, like, you know, what's the role of proteins in particular that phase segregate in these little droplet things and you know, like what do they do and what are they like and what's their life cycle and stuff like that. So I don't do that stuff myself, but I'm very interested. But that's it's not about me, it's all about you. Okay, so Stephen from Johns Hopkins, you're next on my screen. So can you tell us about yourself and then your interest in separation and then we'll have to also get a organize ourselves in terms of writing and reporting, but let's go around the room first. And you're an expert at that because you already did it yesterday.

utterance: Stephen Fried: Yeah, perfect. Well, hi everyone. I'm Stephen Fried. I'm an assistant professor in chemistry and biophysics at Hopkins. I would say our lab is primarily a protein folding biophysics lab, but we make use of a lot of proteomics technologies and basically try to repurpose them so that we can study protein folding sort of more holistically and on more complex systems than the kind of conventional model studies. I would say I got most interested in phase separation when I read Alan Drummond's cell paper from a few years ago that sort of proposed this idea that like these protein coacervates could be functional and not just, you know, sort of a pathological state. But I'm really interested in trying to understand like do cells, you know, purposefully sort of package proteins away to try to protect them or does that carry some sort of proteostatic role and then what allows the cell to then sort of be able to fix a protein, you know, scoop it back out of that collection and resolubilize it again. So I'm really interested in questions like that.

utterance: Cathy Murphy: Awesome, thank you. Okay, Lars, we were in the room yesterday, but this is a new group.

utterance: Lars Plate: Yeah, it's good to see you again. Hello everyone. I'm Lars Plate. I'm an assistant professor at Vanderbilt University in chemistry and biological sciences. And like Stephen, I'm also interested in protein folding processes. But we actually look more at protein-protein interactions and the regulation and dynamics of these complexes and proteostasis pathways and how that's regulated in protein misfolding diseases and then also in virus infections, how they viruses basically take advantage of host cell proteostasis processes. But mass spectrometry is a great tool to study protein interactions, so that's also what what we use mostly in the lab and then coupled with some chemical biology tricks and methods development to kind of probe these processes. And so why I'm interested in phase separation is also in part because it does have this really important role in stress protection and proteostasis. But what's always puzzled me is that yeah, there are these intrinsically disordered proteins that do phase separate under different conditions, but what else gets incorporated into these membraneless organelles and are there sort of passive bystanders that get recruited? Are they still functional and what are they and what are sort of techniques that we can we can interrogate these processes?

utterance: Kathy F. Liu: Yeah, how are you? Hello everyone. I'm Kathy Liu, another Kathy, from Department of Biochemistry and Biophysics at UPenn. So my lab is interested in the function of RNA modifying enzymes mediated RNA modifications and RNA binding proteins in human disorders, particular cancer and neurodegenerative disorders. So we do a lot of CRISPR screening to identify the targets which are particularly important for certain cellular processes. We do liquid chromatography triple quad mass spec to to quantify the levels of modifications and my lab does high-throughput sequencing to look for those modified sites at the human genome. That's the three major techniques that we use. For phase separation, we have our interest lies on two directions. One thing we are particularly interested in nucleolus. We want to know whether the nucleolus is important for the biogenesis and the function of RNA modifications, especially ribosomal RNA modifications and vice versa, whether those modified sites that are participate influence the nucleolar condensates. Another thing is we are interested in sex-specific biocondenstate. My lab identified a list of proteins that is unique to male or females and they are all components in those condensates. So we wonder whether they would influence the condensate related sex-biased human disorders.

utterance: Matthias Heyden: Thank you. I'm at Arizona State University in the School of Molecular Sciences. utterance: Allie Obermeyer: Hi, I am Allie Obermeyer. I am an assistant professor in the chemical engineering department at Columbia. And my group broadly works in the protein and polymer engineering space. So we're frequently trying to engineer and understand protein interactions with both synthetic polymers and biopolymers. And so one of those type of interactions can or many of them, but one that we're particularly interested in can result in phase separation of proteins both in an in vitro system for applications in protein purification and formulation. But then also we have been engineering proteins to artificially control their phase separation inside of living cells. So we do this in bacteria and tuning electrostatic interactions to control phase separation to identify minimal sequences that can promote phase separation and then potentially use these for for engineering purposes. So yeah, so super interested in better better tools to understand the systems we're engineering and and yeah, how we can potentially use some of the things we've engineered to to probe some biological phase separation.

utterance: Stephen Fried: fact that that a computer can predict a structure at all for so much of the proteome. I was almost wondering for the people who work in this field, were they surprised? Because the algorithms that people typically use predict disorder like Disopred and IUPred, they'll give you these numbers like oh like 70, 80% of the human proteome is disordered. It's like well if that's true then how come a computer can predict structures for like 50% of the proteome and like 90% of like the E. coli proteome. So like to me, I thought that was like very much inconsistent with sort of like the view that like Julie Forman-Kay has been proposing that like this is just as common in bacteria as it is in eukaryotes.
